review_title: Only stay for a year or two
pros: Adequate place to start your career, but not sustain or move ahead in your career.
cons: Limited opportunities for upward mobility and promotion, even if you are motivated. Compensation is well below market range.

pros: The artist community is indescribable.  Many of the faculty and staff are some of the most amazing  people I’ve met. The students often make me laugh and many of them have brilliant minds. There truly is diversity amongst the students and staff. Paycheck necessity aside, ultimately students, faculty, staff, and being constantly around art and creativity contribute to my satisfaction working for the institution.
cons: PAFA is a non profit organization so the pay is very low for many of us. Anything that makes staff and students unique or who have a useful and unique skill(s) seem to always be completely and utterly exploited. In personal experience  being kind when rejecting an additional/ new task that you cannot honestly accommodate does nothing but isolate you. Morale is low everywhere and the burnout can be unreal. Raises don’t exist, and what’re promotions?

job_title: Venue Sales Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Working in the heart of Philadelphia at the oldest art museum and art school in the United States. Talented students!
cons: No ability to think ideas outside of your reporting manager. too much behind the scenes and behind your back politics going on. If you excel at backstabbing and have the ability to relate to your colleagues like high school clique factions, you will do well at PAFA. If "Heathers" went to work at an art college, they'd work at PAFA.

review_title: PAFA has the potential to be so much more.
pros:
•Many excellent and wonderful co-workers if not-so-excellent management.
•General environment can be very positive depending upon the department and area(s) you work in. 
•Health plan is okay if you can afford it.
•Access to 403b with 4% deposit matching.
•Access to 1 (non-credit) Continuing Education class a semester.
•Possibly provides more access to the art community - this varies and can depend on you.
•Great potential.
cons:
•Highly bureaucratic (top-down organization).
•Complacent upper management.
•Lack of communication and organization throughout.
•Lack of innovation, coupled with a wastefulness and disregard for in-house talents/resources..
•Lack of training, with much information being lost with each new turnover (which is fairly high).
•Severe wage gap; not only do the ranking staff's yearly salaries range from 350k to 105k, but there bonuses can be as much as (or in some cases more than) the average employees earnings, which are around 20k (18-36k).
•Low pay for regular employees is not generally comparable to workload, experience or other institution.
•Raises are not based on performance, are rare, and are low (3% e,g.).
•Employees rarely feel respected, secure, informed or incentivized.
•Employees are often under-supplied with resources and over tasked (a department could be comprised of 1-2 people or work for multiple departments).
•Low, if any, professional development.
•No real outlet/resource for employees to voice concerns or affect change; few supervisors will try to help and HR is there to uphold organizational interests, not to be a resource for employees.
•Growing increasingly more corporatized - loosing track of goals as an art school and museum as well as responsibilities to students, faculty and the community.

pros: Continuing Ed department is great to work with, lots of room to design courses and they're open to new ideas for workshops. Department also really forward thinking and looking to expand their offerings. Good salary.
